summary:
I talked so much shit about this movie when it first got announced...
I mean Sony didn’t really have a good track record when it...
body:
I talked so much shit about this movie when it first got announced…

I mean Sony didn’t really have a good track record when it came to Spider-Man movies since 2007. Amazing Spider-Man was okay I guess, but they ruined what they had with the sequel.

Then the emails got leaked. And Jesus Christ, you could tell these people were out of touch. Out of touch with people and out of touch with the character. I mean seriously? Spider-Man as a mudrun, humble bragging, EDM DJ? Spider-Man vs the Amazing Spider-Man?

And then they announced that it was going to be about Miles, a character I liked but I knew a lot of “older” comic book fans had a problem with because of “diversity.” A character whose origin story was dependent on the fact that Peter Parker died and surely they wouldn’t show Spider-Man dying in a kids movie, right? I could see it already. They were going to completely Emoji Movie the character and make Miles even more hated.

But then the trailers came out, and it looked GOOD. And the soundtrack was teased, and it sounded GOOD. And the movie released, and it was so goddamn GOOD I saw it twice in the theaters, once by myself.

The comics code authority callback in the very beginning,

getting in touch with Miles’ Hispanic background instead of simply painting him as purely a black character,

treating Spider-Man’s death with such beauty especially in the wake of Stan Lee’s passing,

the way the different art styles clash and perfectly accentuate each character’s uniqueness,

giving us a flawed Peter Parker, one who has his own issues to overcome with Miles’ help,

I fucking love this movie. I cannot stop talking about it with my friends. I cannot stop listing all the things that everyone involved got right about the character.

It’s the best Spider-Man story outside of the comics since the PS4 game. It’s my favorite Spider-Man movie (yeah it’s better than 2, @me). It’s probably my favorite comic book movie ever. I love it so much and I’m so worried Sony is going to shit the bed with the sequel because I know Avi Arad and Amy Pascal are grubby and greedy and so eager to start a cinematic universe that they’re willing to sacrifice quality to sell more toys.

Peter eating an apple: They say an apple a day keeps the doctor away.
Tony: You know, I'm technically a doctor kid, I graduated...
body:
Peter eating an apple: They say an apple a day keeps the doctor away.

Tony: You know, I’m technically a doctor kid, I graduated with a PhD.

Peter throwing the apple at Tony: BEGONE THOT, YEET!

summary:
Tony Stark in space: well, might as well enjoy one last song before I die. 
Turns on the helmets last song, Toto starts...
body:
Tony Stark in space: well, might as well enjoy one last song before I die.

Turns on the helmets last song, Toto starts playing:

Tony, groaning: god dammit Peter.



Peter in the soul stone peeking up: Someone’s disrespecting Toto.

summary:
Spider-Man debuted in 1962 in Amazing Fantasy #15 and it’s been 57 years
 since but due to time sliding time scale and the...
caption:
Spider-Man debuted in 1962 in Amazing Fantasy #15 and it’s been 57 years since but due to time sliding time scale and the nature of comic books the character has aged only so much and his story gets updated and adapted for adapted for modern times. Spider-Man: Life Story is a mini about the life of 1960′s Peter Parker aging in real time up to the modern times and how each decade affects his life The story starts in 1966 with Peter being 19 years old with the last issue possibly ending in 2019 and Peter being 72 years old.

The first issue partially deals with Peter’s feelings about the Vietnam war and how that affects his life (like Flash Thompson joining to serve in the war and Peter wondering if he should join too). We also get a glimpse of Iron Man (who was then thought to be Tony Stark’s body guard) joining the war effort (and seeing how Tony’s first origin is tied the Vietnam war it makes sense) and Captain America being pressured to join the war.

We also get this wonderful interaction between Peter and Steve and it’s pretty true to how their relationship is in the regular comics. Steve giving Peter some advice, support and guidance while also treating him with respect and as an equal. He doesn’t even tell Peter what to do because he understands that Peter needs to makes his own choices and sees that Peter is already a selfless and responsible person and Steve trusts he will make the best choice for himself.

This is how you do a younger and older hero relationship without making it into a mentor/sidekick one.

From Spider-Man: Life Story #1
